Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: Judi Dench continues her role as the sort of anchor of a group of elderly unmarried women who live in the small rural English town of Cranford.Return to Cranford inlcudes two episodes that pick up where Cranford left off.  There are major changes afoot when the people of Cranford are forced to deal with the possibilty of the railroad reaching their isolated, thuogh largely contented town.Death and life continue to be the hallmarks of this story, as well as conniving characters, and characters who are entrenched in their views.Can Cranford survive the coming of progress, represented by the railroad, or will it be forever lost?  You will have to watch in order to find out.I found the acting, costuming, and story lines to be fantastic!  This set of tails is, probably 1/2 star dimmer than the "Cranford", but it still warrants 5 stars in my book.If you like period drama, BBC productions, and historical fiction, you will like "Return to Cranford"5 stars.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: So sad that this was the ending of this story.  I wish it would have gone on and on because we so enjoyed it!!!

reviewText: After thoroughly enjoying the first Cranford with all its charm and appeal, this subsequent series was a great disappointment.  With its splendid pedigree of actors retained, there is no lack of effort on their part but even the excellent cast cannot not fix a script/direction that is sorely lacking in most all aspects and one which renders every situation as contrived and insipid. It would have been wonderful to experience a continuation of all the heartwarming aspects of the first series but this particular rendition falls dismally short.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: EXCELLENT PERIOD PIECE - I watch many, many period piece movies and series. I see excellent costumes true to their period. Also, I look for furniture, decoration on room walls, outside grounds, clarity of voice and brightness of coloring, not just how the characters play their parts. I only give 5 stars when a movie or series passes all the tests, and I feel this one deserves a 5. I do wish this series was longer though.

reviewText: With lots of material left over from the original "Cranford", it was always a given that we'd get to see more delightful stories from the rural Cheshire village and it's endearing inhabitants.  These two 90-minute episodes finally tie up the stories of Miss Matty, Harry, Miss Galindo, Lady Ludlow and Cranford's irrepressible "Amazons" Miss Pole (Imelda Staunton), Mrs Forrester (Julia McKenzie), Mrs Jamieson (Barbara Flynn), and Miss Tomkinson (Deborah Findlay).It's been a year since the events of the last series of "Cranford", and much has changed in the community.  Dr Harrison and Sophy have left the district, and so have Jessie and Major Gordon.  Widower Mr Buxton (Jonathan Pryce), an old resident of Cranford, returns with his now-grown son William (Tom Hiddleston) and spirited ward Erminia (Michelle Dockery).  On the other side of the social divide is the lovely Peggy Bell (Jodie Whittaker).  Cranford's newest romance has a lot riding against it, though, with Buxton very vocal in his displeasure at Peggy eventually becoming William's wife.  Mrs Jamieson's sister-in-law Lady Glenmire (Celia Imrie) is another enchanting newcomer.After closing down her enterprising parlour tea shop, Miss Matty (Dame Judi Dench) has settled into the joyful role of being a second mother to Tilly, the little daughter of Martha and Jem (Claudie Blakley and Andrew Buchan), whilst her brother Peter (Nicholas Le Prevost) provides the necessary money to keep the Jenkyns household going.  To her joy, Miss Matty once again has an extended visit from Mary Smith (Lisa Dillon), who reveals that she has firmly resolved to call an end to her engagement in order to set forth on a career as a novelist.At Hanbury Court, Lady Ludlow (Francesca Annis) is dying, but still firmly clinging to her land, which is constantly threatened by the ever-encroaching railway.  Miss Galindo (Emma Fielding) finally manages to secure Lady Ludlow's son Lord Septimus (Rory Kinnear) to return during a brief trip from his villa at Lake Lugano, but Lady Ludlow passes away before he arrives.  When Septimus unravels the bleak financial condition of the estate and realises that he'll have to eventually pay back Lady Ludlow's mortgage into the inheritance of young Harry Gregson (Alex Etel), he attempts to manipulate the boy into accepting a smaller immediate payment in lieu of the larger amount owed, underestimating the powerful ally that Harry has in Miss Galindo, and her fervent quest to see Mr Carter's last wishes carried out.The central dilemma in town remains the prospect of the railway "invading" the peace and calm of Cranford itself.  It's an argument which is pitting father against son, neighbour against neighbour, and driving away many valued workers, including Jem, who has become one of the local craftsmen drawn to the higher wages offered by the railroad company.  Despite her own fears and reservations, Miss Matty organises for her closest friends to experience rail travel first-hand, and unwittingly triggers a series of dramas with wide-reaching consequences for several Cranford residents...As in the original CRANFORD miniseries, there is much to love and savour in this all-too-brief sequel.  Screenwriter Heidi Thomas is one of my personal favourites and she is a great practitioner in the art of how to write for period drama.  She has a particular knack for immersing herself in the period and creating a true dialogue, with great feeling and affection for her characters, and quite frequently hilarious.  I know of no other costume drama writer who can write such brilliant comedy - and with the antics of Miss Pole, Mrs Forrester and Mrs Jamieson, Heidi Thomas is in her element.The performances remain utterly delightful.  Only a top-drawer series like CRANFORD could attract the likes of Dame Judi Dench, Imelda Staunton, Julia McKenzie, Jonathan Pryce, Francesca Annis and Nicholas Le Prevost; in addition to bright young costume drama stars like Michelle Dockery ("Downton Abbey") and Matthew McNulty ("Lark Rise to Candleford"). It's like a Theatre Rep company from the good old days.You'll never want to leave this town...
summary: more delights to be savoured in enchanting "Cranford" sequel

reviewText: Beware!  SOME SPOILERS!Since Z. Hayes did an excellent job reviewing the general content of the film, I won't go over it again and I'm writing this review from the viewpoint that you, whom is reading this, have already seen the first Cranford.  This continuation does leave you wanting but not in a good way.  The film seems unfinished with a bunch of half attempts to cover potential plotholes (unless there is plan to make another continuation after "Return to Cranford" with further explanation as to what happens--if that's the case, I take back those last two sentences).While the original Cranford seemed to be light and fun, in spite of life's obvious tragedies, this film is far more dismal.  Some of the story, rather than building up anticipation for what's going to happen next seemed as if it were there as time filler.  Also there were way too many parts that were just plain cheesy.  Case in point, Mattie is awaiting her friends at the train station.  She has urged them to try out the train in view of the town's attempt at progression and modernization that has been a huge concern for our heroines.  No one has arrived.  The train pulls up and comes to a halt while smoke emerges from underneath the train and out of nowhere Matttie's four friends emerges from the smoke arm in arm.  LOL!What really saved Part 1 of this set is the appearance of Septimus, Lady Ludlow's long-awaited son, and his dealings with Harry Gregson, the beneficiary of Mr. Carter's estate.  Other than this, there's not much meat to the other storylines.  Of course, there is the inevitable love story (which is always a good thing) but still even that was predictable and not that all convincing.The beginning of Part 2 is much better with the discovery and agony of forbidden love affairs, a broken engagement, a defying of social expectations, and some of the fun gossipy deliciousness of the first Cranford but it starts get corny again towards the end.I hate somewhat comparing the two Cranfords but I'm sure that my being hopelessly prejudiced by the first (LOVED IT!!) dashed the high hopes to the second.  For me, the movie was just ok.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: They do it the right way across the pond! The Brittish have these period series nailed! Superb acting! Excellent plot line! and good, clean wholsome fun! Not like the trash put out here in the U.S.

reviewText: It's fun to spend a little time with some of the characters from the deservedly successful "Cranford," but that's about all that can be said for this weak 2-part sequel.  As others have pointed out, it's a much thinner stitchery of Gaskell's work, presumably to capitalize on the performance of the first series.  Worth watching for the pleasure of seeing some wonderful actors, but it's really only in the "mildly diverting" category.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: I love and own the original BBC production of Cranford (have watched it several times), was excited to hear that a three-hour "Return to Cranford" sequel was to be released on January 19th, and decided to pre-order it.  I must admit I was disappointed in Part One, which I watched on my local PBS station, WGBH-Boston, last Sunday night.  It felt contrived and flat, seemed poorly written, and was missing several pivotal actors.  Only the fine acting by Judi Dench and the comical Imelda Staunton redeemed this production.  Where were Dr. Harrison and his bride, Sophie Hutton (did they leave Cranford -- inpossible!), did Mrs. Rose marry the doctor and retire with him to some warm clime?, why did they have to kill off Martha (especially so soon), what about comical Caroline Tomkins and her new butcher husband, why did they replace Matty's dashing brother Peter with a far less attractive, eccentric actor (and weren't we left thinking at the end of the original Cranford that a romance might develop between Peter and Miss Pole? Instead he gives her a bird - huh?, leading to a slightly funny but kind of ridiculous "cage" scene), and I can't believe that Mary is engaged to a Mr. Turnbull (I thought she'd stay with Matty forever or at least for a few years since a year earlier, in the original Cranford, she denied any interest in marriage or babies).  It does seem natural for Jessie to have left for India with Major Gordon, but still I miss her (her sensitivity and emotional depth are features sadly lacking in this new production, at least Part One since I have yet to watch Part Two).  I guess I wanted everyone to pick up where they left off.  Because I am so curious about the missing characters, I really don't care about the new people -- although we heard so much about Septimus in the original Cranford that it makes sense he should arrive when Lady Ludlow dies.  Speaking of which, I didn't like that she died.  I wanted to see more of how the great Lady (and her views) changed with time and as a result of her relationship with Mr. Carter, now deceased, and Harry Gregson as he becomes educated and grows into a gentleman (and why didn't we see even one quick scene of his studies with the Reverend Hutton?).  The scene in which Lady Ludlow died was ridiculous -- sickly as she is, she stands for hours in one place and in a crooked posture waiting for her son's arrival and then all of a sudden falls to the floor dead.  Bottom line:  Part One at least just didn't work.  I had planned to watch Part Two tomorrow evening and then cancel my pre-order since the DVD wasn't scheduled for release until Tuesday.  But I got an e-mail that Amazon shipped it on Friday (and then promptly dropped the price by $.50).  Oh well, I'll put it in the drawer with the similarly disappointing sequel to the brilliant and entertaining 2002 Forsyte Saga.1/20/10 Update:  I watched Part Two of Return to Cranford this past Sunday night and thought it better than Part One.  Then, on Tuesday, the copy of Return to Cranford that I had pre-ordered arrived (and I was credited $.50).  I watched the series again over the past two evenings and I like it much better on second viewing, so I would increase my rating to 3.5 stars.  It's still not as good as the original, but well done nonetheless.  Now I plan to re-watch the original Cranford to compare them.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: How do you follow an act like Cranford?  With another drama, brilliant in it's own right.  Not by trying to re-visit past triumphs, much as we long to do so. The proper successor to Cranford has yet to come along, in my opinion, and it probably won't be about Cranford, but "Return to Cranford" was great fun, nonetheless.Return to Cranford  stumbles perhaps against the block of the--what happens after the story ends?--mentality that plagues most sequels. We do get to see what happens to most of our beloved characters, with the notable exception of young Dr. Harrison. He's only mentioned in passing as having a wife and not being there anymore, which is odd, since so much of the drama revolved around him in Cranford. In the sequel, most of the drama revolves around the railroad construction, halted by Lady Ludlow's refusal to sell her land. Through a series of circumstances, the construction goes through an "on-again, off-again" cycle that feels contrived, and then culminates in an action-packed railroad event that also, in retrospect, feels contrived. Perhaps the writers hadn't come up with a solid character-driven story before they were up against a deadline. As a result we get this circumstance-driven drama that depends upon our pre-existing knowledge of and affection for the characters to get our attention. Had this story been about unknown characters, I doubt it would have much real interest at all.There is also a strange sense that Cranford is a set, rather than a town, in this sequel. It feels less populated, somehow, and the costumes and rooms less detailed.  Perhaps because of the way it was filmed? They must have reused the same costumes and sets as the original film, but this production does look subtly different. More like t.v. and less like cinema.Mattie's brother, Peter, is played by a different actor, which is distracting. There was something so remarkable, sort of ethereal, about the first Peter's physical appearance that it's dissapointing to see him played by this different actor.  The character adds very little to the story here, other than comic antics, so it's puzzling why Peter was included, if the original actor was apparently unavailable, especially since others are so pointedly missing. In fact, I wondered if the producers did a roll-call of who would be available for filming before the writers got to work on the screenplay, some of the omissions are so arbitrary.Lady Ludlow's son, the contemptible Septimus, appears onscreen finally and his story begins to develop, only to trail off. We never find out how his shenanigans turn out, despite the fact that they have a crucial bearing on the outcomes of several other characters.None of this means that I consider "Return to Cranford" a dismal failure. Not at all. For one thing, look at what it must be compared to. What sequel wouldn't suffer by comparison? I expected some notching-down of the quality when I ordered it, and intended to enjoy visiting with these characters again, anyway. And I did enjoy it. Although I have to say that, hokey a plot twist as it was, if Harry Gregson hadn't fogged up that mirror, I was prepared to be VERY dissapointed in the writers at that point! Enough bumping off of great characters, already!The actors, as always, were their superb selves.  The performances are as satisfying as they could be with that screenplay. Good enough, in fact, to distract from the lackluster story.If you're expecting to relive "Cranford" in all it's glory, don't. If you're prepared to enjoy some very fine t.v.-grade writing and production values, and revel in spending time with the beloved "Cranford" dames, then by all means, get yourself a copy of "Return to Cranford".  I'm keeping mine.
summary: If You Film it, Cranford Fans will come...
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

At any rate I've become a huge fan and even bought season 2, instead of waiting for it to come out on Amazon Prime!  Now...hurry with season 3, please.

reviewText: If you have read the book, then you may be more pleased with "Return to Cranford" than "Cranford."I simply adore the book, and I read it whenever I want to visit the ladies at Cranford so that is usually once a year.  That leads me to say Cranford pt 1 was a disappointment because some of the best scenes from the book were omitted (but delightfully included in pt 2.) And even more frustrating; those scenes were replaced with characters and story lines from Elizabeth Gaskell's other books.The day after "Return to Cranford" aired on PBS I was anxiously awaiting my mail delivery to see if it arrived and I watched it again as soon as I could get the wrapper off!!All of the actors in this movie are superb, the writing is well done and this dvd deserves a place on your shelf next to "Wives and Daughters," "Pride and Prejudice" and "The Way We Live Now."

Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: I enjoyed "Return to Cranford" very much, more so after the second viewing.  During the first viewing I was a little distracted by thinking about "what happened to so and so?" Also, the two new families are introduced a bit too quickly and so I didn't fully get into their characters until the second time around.  Like the first Cranford, this second installment has humor, sadness, the testing of friendships, the struggle between the old and the new and a sweet romance between two young people.  At first it bothered me that Dr. Harrison wasn't around, but then I thought about it.  How many period films continue a love story after the marriage?  Also, a huge part of the story in the first Cranford was the misunderstanding of Dr. Harrison's affections, so once that was resolved and he and Sophie were married, his story was told.  I really didn't see him being the heroic younger doctor again in Return to Cranford.  That was done enough in the first installment and it wouldn't have been as compelling in the second one.  In Return to Cranford, I absolutely loved the touching romance between William and Peggy.  He was so handsome, kind and resolved, and she showed that she was wise and strong in spite of her social awkwardness.  A few things keep me from giving this piece a 5 star review.  Perhaps I'll understand it better after more viewings, but I couldn't figure out exactly what happened with Harry and the estate.  Did he lose his inheritance?  I thought this story line was confusing and lacking in resolution.  Also, why was Mary gone in the beginning?  I didn't fully understand where she was and I thought it was strange to bring her back just to have her leave again.  Also, Mattie is almost financially destitute in the first Cranford, yet in this one, she has been able to save up a fairly large amount of money.  Is this because her brother Peter has his own income and contributes to her support?  I wasn't sure.  I was a bit disappointed in the ending, feeling it to be overly sentimental.  It seemed odd to me that characters who probably wouldn't even know how to dance (specifically Peggy and Harry) were dancing like old pros.  In spite of these minor irritations, Return to Cranford is definitely a movie I will keep and watch several more times in the future.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: It would have been impossible to top "Cranford" but this second part can take us back to that sleepy hamlet.  Many of the outstanding original cast members that were so wonderful return to reprise their roles in this continuation.There has been a two year gap since part one ended.  I must agree with a previous reviewer who found "Return" a bit sadder and emptier than the original. I loved the original story so much that a sequel could have never done it justice in my eyes no matter what. Even then it was far better than a dozen other sequels.Enjoy the film!

Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: I really enjoyed it...I love British period dramas and this one was up to par.  I would watch it again
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: This sequel to the original "Cranford"screams -hastily put together and suffers from the sort of sequel problems we have seen in so many movies over the years. As previous writers have commented, storylines are weak and at times quite silly, too many new characters -none very interesting. Still, anything with Judi Dench and her staunch band of women cant be all bad and young Alex Edel is a real star in the making and has a more mature and important role here. But if they were going to return, more time should have been spent on  script.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: Many of the interesting characters from the main series were not there anymore.  It was very sad.  While I very highly recommend "Cranford" I regret that I cannot do the same for "The Return."
summary: Not nearly as interesting as Cranford
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: After thoroughly enjoying Cranford, I was quite disappointed with the Return to Cranford. There was too many drastic changes, too many added new characters and not enough of first cast. The story jumped ahead too far and I just felt lost and couldn't get into it.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: My favorite movies have always been foreign. I hardly ever watch American Movies. I had already bought the first Cranford for my collection and so very glad "Return to Cranford" was made.Loved it.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: Excellent movie, i loved it, have different stories and the characters are very good especially Judi Dench who is tremendous actress. The theme of this film is very interesting and versatile
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: I enjoyed Cranford 1 and 2 with equal satisfaction and both seasons were very satisfying to me.  I like the eye to detail and settings, and the cast is amazing.  There are a few objections by some purist Cranston fans that this is a little more contrived than Season 1 but I dont agree.  The stories are very feasible and the acting superb by all,especially Dame Judy Dench.  All the characters ring true and I wept and laughed and fell in love as I watched.  It is well worth your money and your time to be in Cranford again and again. You will not be disappointed and yes, Love is the final answer.
summary: Like being back with good friends
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: I loved the Cranford series and was looking for Return to Cranford on Amazon for  some time.  Although the first one is good, Return to Cranford is even better with a more interesting storyline, characters, set designs, costumes, and performances. A huge fan of Dame Judy Dench, it's a joy to watch her in this series. She perfectly captures the sensibilities of a spinster in 1840s England, without being overly sentimental or unrealistic. I'm glad I bought it on Amazon Instant, rather than rent it, since this will be one watched again and again.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: We loved this ... my 13yod particularly enjoys watching (and re-watching ... and re-watching).Well worth the couple of dollars to "buy"!

reviewText: Loved it

reviewText: I love this period piece.  A nice mix of seriousness along with a bit of comedy thrown in.  Miss Mattie is definitely a favorite, but all of the characters have interesting quirks.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: I'd give this series a 4.5 star. It took a little bit for me to get used to it. Then I got hooked on it. It was really neat to see how people lived in that era. I enjoyed the actors and actresses, they really did a great job :)
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: Sentimental small town movie starring Judi Dench:  at first it was questionable seeing her play a mild-mannered sister, but after two episodes of her submissive role to her domineering sister, the sister is gone, then she becomes more palatable.  Still, quite a different role for Dame Dench.  The movie is sweet and charming. I enjoyed seeing the clothing and manners of a small English country town.  Later watched The Return to Cranford. It was made in 2009 and only two seasons were available.  I would like to have seen more, but maybe that was all that were made.
summary: Charming English BBC movie starring Dame Judi Dench
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: This series is probably the closest to "real life" at the time, with gossips, social expectations and unexpected deaths. Was really happy with the costumes and imagery, nothing was "updated" for modern tastes in a major way.  Excellent and entertaining, with some really top-notch actors!

reviewText: What can I say about a program that is written so well, acted by some of the FINEST British actresses (and actors!) - it is a trip back in time with a sly sense of humor and some cheeky good fun. I wish there were more of it...it's addictive!!

reviewText: Great high & lows in the series. Couldn't wait til the next episode. Great period of time & they captured it well.

reviewText: If you like these early British towns and values, you'll like this.  It take unexpected twists wnd turns and makes itself enjoyable.

reviewText: It is a wonderful movie.  The only reason I gave it only four stars is because the original Cranford was better.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: If you're at all interested in this production, do ignore the detractors and purchase this without hesitation.  Admittedly it may not rival the original, but it is still a great pleasure.  Watching Dench, Staunton, and McKenzie together is akin to watching a master class in acting.  Yes, some narrative threads, as others have pointed out, begin and end too quickly, but just being in the company of Cransford's inhabitants again is wonderful.  I thoroughly enjoyed my three hours back in Cranford, and hope that the BBC sees fit to take me back again with another series of episodes.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: Judi Dench is one of my favoite actresses. " Cranford" and "Return to Cranford" are wonderful DVD's and should be enjoyed fully by those who enjoy the early English historical pieces.  I would not hesitate to purchase this DVD.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: The Brits know how to tell a story, everything was so well done and every detail was authentic.  Great Story!
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: HUMOROUS WITH EXCELLENT ACTORS AND ACTRESSES.  SCENERY IS BEAUTIFUL.  I THOUGHT IT WAS FREE BUT NOW SEE A CHARGE TO MY ACCOUNT?
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: Let this act as my review for both seasons one and two.Don't get me wrong by the rating, Cranford is a charming miniseries with an excellent ensemble, and it's extremely humorous in more than a few instances. It's just that after hearing my mother rave about it for months, I expected something different when I finally sat down to watch it. Those interested in this series are likely to get what they're looking for, which makes it a worthwhile piece of entertainment for most, it's just not for me.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: The original Cranford series was not devoid of painful moments, but there was a balance of joy and grief.  The sequel seems to overbalance on the grief side, with two major losses.  One seemed to sacrifice the storyline for excessive dramatic purpose, a loss from which I think the series could not easily recover.There seemed to be many holes in this series compared to the former one. No explanation was given for why Cranford went from two doctors to none.  And so much of what went on seemed to make little sense, or the characters indulged in excessive acts for no good reason except to furnish dramatic content -- Lady Ludlow's final stand, Jem Hearn's decision, and Harry's inexplicable comings and goings.  Even the town, which should have been booming (even if the railroad was going to be a few miles rather than right at their doorstep) was supposedly in an economic tailspin. After all, Jem was run off his feet by his business even before the railroad came.For those of us that paid attention and really took in the details of the first series, it's not so easy for us to swallow whole a hasty, ill conceived and ill justified second series.OTOH, there's enough of Cranford in it to make it passable to good, if not the excellent rating the first series got.  Imelda Stanton  and her feathers alone is worth the watch.I can only hope we get more Cranford in future, though I wish they would  do the first series  and its devoted viewers justice and take a little more care to make a more sensible storyline.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: A sequel to this series needs to be done.  Seemingly ordinary lives aren't always so ordinary after all.  Love the town & countryside, the horses, etc.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: I'll be brief. While I loved the original production of CRANFORD, I couldn't get into RETURN TO CRANFORD because I never got past the fact that the actresses looked like frumpy women dressed in straight-off-the-rack period-piece costumes. In short, this seemed an inauthentic and uninspired production and a waste of exceptional talent. When I wish to return to Cranford, I'll watch the wonderful original, thank you very much.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: This is a heart warming story about a community and friendship....very endearing....I am surprised it has not been renewed again.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: Love this as much as the first series. The best surprise is that Tim Curry shows up in these episodes. According to the commentary he was so enchanted by the first episodes, so he told his agent to make sure he made it into any future episodes. Love Crawford from top to bottom! Wish I could visit this village.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: I loved the original "Cranford" on Masterpiece Theatre and have read the book "The Cranford Chronicles" (which you should all read!).  I have the dvd and have watched it often and find something new in it each time.  The story ends with many story lines tied up but also, some options for future story lines as the characters age and grow.  Brilliant story and cast.  Then comes "Return to Cranford".  I won't spoil the story for you but while beautiful to look at, the story is shallow and meaningless and except for a few moments, you really won't care (everyone is against the railroad but no one has ever RIDDEN a train, soooooo).  Most of the original actors are there but it seemed to me it was done out of pity for those of us who loved the original and wouldn't want to see new people in these roles or (horrors!) for the money.  Stick to the original and imagine the future.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: The first Cranford is a favorite in our home:  it has well drawn characters in deep and subtle situations that are fraught with emotion, with historical change, with personal development and hope.  It is one of the most beautiful mini-series I have ever seen, yet never gets precious or maudlin.  SO it was only a matter of time before we got this one.On the one hand, there are many  strengths to this production.  The characters develop, some in very surprising yet believable ways, including tragedies, changes in plans, and unexpected love.  This is very fun and makes it much more than a simple follow-on.  The period atmosphere is also elegant and plush, vividly and accurately evoking a period in history - my kids had many questions about it.  On the other hand, the story feels rushed.  Not only is there too much going on too fast, but the viewer lacks the time to integrate it all.  That translates into a kind of overload and a complete lack of the meditative, almost poetic, pauses and asides that makes the first production a meal to savor.As far as the plot goes, the train remains a controversial issue, with many complications and the need for continuing negotiations with owners and changes of attitude.  (This was one reason why train networks spread in the US much more swiftly.)  The son of the reigning aristocrat also returns too late, though after some brutal machinations he is whisked away all too quickly.  The wonderful boy who is charged with getting an education in order to create a school for the town also faces a significant and unexpected crisis.  Nonetheless, while most of the principal characters are there, the doctor no longer serves the town.  His loss is partially made up with a group of very good new characters, but again, it feels rushed.  One very interesting character is a Scottish aristocrat, who arrives in town to visit a relative - sparking a major fight - and astounds everyone with her decision to stay.  That is all I can say without giving away too much.I would recommend this to fans of the first series.  It is very good, if not as perfectly outstanding as we had hoped.
summary: more than a knockoff, but lacks the depth of the original series
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: It is hard to imagine anybody buying this DVD without having seen the original "Cranford" beforehand. And on that understanding, how one receives this sequel film is totally dependent on one's attitude towards the first. The original "Cranford" is a classic period English small town morality play. It is superbly performed by a galaxy of solid - even great - British actors who are all so relaxed and at home in their roles that it all seems totally real and convincing. Behaviour standards, class attitudes, subtleties of language depending who is addressing who, the sets, camera work and directing are all faultless. The transformation of Judy Dench, the awful impact of thoughtless gossip, the almost unbelievable naivete of some of the characters... it all adds up to a perfect little work of art. The sequel, Return to Cranford, is pretty well what you'd expect. The Dench character cannot transform again, the gossips are recognized and so you anticipate their effect, the hand is dealt from the same deck, but the trumps have already been played. In other words, it is much the same, but not quite as satisfying. There are a few new twists - nicely developed. The producers and screenplay writers work hard to get fresh dynamics into the mix, possible by the progress of the railway (approaching modernity and changing mores) and the actors all do as well as before although the stars from the first film seem at times just a little jaded, and it is possible to wonder why a few from the first weren't brought back - where did they go, and why? Having said that, note that I rated this with four stars - but I'd give the first film five. If you loved "Cranford" you'll certainly enjoy "Return to Cranford", but don't expect it to be better.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: Purchased this as a gift for my Mother she loves Dame Judy Dench. Purchase the first and this second series have to say I enjoyed them also, period series like this if done well are a look back in time and BBC really can produce these like no-one else. This second series did seem to have a lot of misfortune for several characters felt sometimes too much. But overall an excellent follow-up.

reviewText: Great!  Very well done and it kept my interest up to the end,  I was so sad when it ended.

reviewText: In many ways I enjoyed this more than the original offering of "Cranford" and I loved the original. Don't you hate the fact that a good book, great play or a wonderful series must come to an end? This was "Cranford". I loved it so much I wanted to become a part of the group. Along comes "Return to Cranford" and I was, once again a part of the group. I could find out what had happened to each one of my friends, while I was away. To quote some very old commercial"ad, try it you'll like it, maybe, like me, love it!
summary: Return to Cranford" or as I prefer, Catching Up With Old Friends
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewerName: Shirley "Respector of the Power of Language"
reviewText: Enjoyable story of a time and place no longer seen. A small town community interacts in all sorts of situations. It was worth it to me just to see the lace that places a part in one of the episodes. Entertaining and ultimately, a reaffirmation of life and the people who live it.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: I can't say enough about British drama.  They have it nailed.  Cranford, in my opinion, is a masterpiece of entertainment.  I have watched this DVD, so many times and have enjoyed the characters in their small community of Cranford.  Reminds me of the town in which I grew up, where all the neighbors knew what was going on in everyone's life, and gossiped, but not in a mean spirited way. The story centers around two spinsters sisters, Deborah (played by Eileen Atkins) and Mary (played by Judy Dench) in 1842.  The elder sister, Deborah, is the epitome of correctness. Her sister, Mary, is not so rigid in social correctness and a little softer in her demeanor. This is not to be missed............I recommend it, Highly.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: Having loved CRANFORD, the original BBC series shown on Masterpiece Theatre, I placed my advance order for Return to Cranford with great expectations.  Unable to wait for the DVD to rlease I watch the two part series when it aired on Masterpiece Theatre, and found myself enjoying the first of its two parts and looking forward to the second and final installment, only to discover that it lacked everything that made the Cranford expirience what it was.Return to Cranford picks up a year after "Cranford" ends.  While the four women at the center of Cranford life remain, many of the other charecters have also gone including the village doctors, without any explaination.  Given how important it was for the village to have a doctor in the first series, and then to have the doctors absent without any explainations seemed odd. The cast is smaller and many of the charecters that drove the first series are gone, one would think that the actors have gone onto others things.  However in this series the town seems less full of English life, which is what made the original Cranford so glorious.The first of the two episodes is the better of the two.  One story line involves Lady Ludlow and her faith in her son who has failed her at every turn.  This thread seems to come off the best.  Another story line inolving actor Jonathan Price and his family - and a budding romance is keeps your interest, but it is a pale comparision to the romance in the previous episode as neither actors involved have any spark. This episode's finale has the women of Cranford doing what they do best, and perhaps they should have ended everything right here and left best alone.However in the second episode, while the town and the relationships of the people of Cranford are put to the test, the production falls completly apart.  Too many story lines are processed too quickly - including the introduction of a new charecter and a surprise wedding go full circle -  while the story of Harry and Lord Septimus is left unresoved as is the story line of Mary Smith who appears and then disappears.  In one scene, Dame Judy Dench goes to the Railway Camp in search of another charecter and she just seems very lost - and this becomes an untentional metaphore for the viewer, who is also lost in this scramble to tie up loose ends.  But it the quick cut to, and the chop, chop, chop pacing throws the whole production off kilter. And then, probably because they killed off people in one railway explosion in the first series, the producers thought a second railway explosion would be a nice way to get rid of a few problems.  But the explosion, and accident, and its aftermath is sloppily done.  The final event with no reason, is the return of Jem and Tillie - why?  Not that I'm complaining, but it just happens.This two part event just made me feel as if the producers had the best of intentions, but ran out of time and money.  And that is sad.  Cranford deserves better than the lot it was dealt.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: My wife and I really enjoy the first Cranford film/series.  It is truly excellent in pretty much every way.  Unfortunately, this effort is not nearly on par with the first.  The script, character development, story-telling, and pacing are lacking.  I think the film is still entertaining enough to be worth watching as long as you enter with lowered expectations.  In particular the actors do their best with what they are given.  The performances of Imelda Staunton and Judi Dench are worth seeing.  Other than that, where the original used the characters to good effect, this new series almost universally wastes them.Others have commented that the first part wasn't great.  It may not have been great, but still left the door open for a promising conclusion.  The second part is borderline not good and is the undoing of the film.Suggested Alternative Title:It pains me, but I can't give my suggested alternative title as it might constitute a spoiler.  Suffice it to say it's dripping with metaphorical irony.  For more, see the comments on my review.
summary: Not Nearly as Excellent as the Original
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: This was good to watch. Old fashioned values in the community. I liked it. It shows how change can be good also.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: I  WILL  TELL  YOU  THE  HONEST  TRUTH  ABOUT  THE  DVD  RETURN  TO  CRANFORD,  NOT  WHAT  I  EXPECTED, IT  WAS  LIKE  THE  FIRST  PART  OF  CRANFORD  WAS  THE  BIGINING  AND  THE  END  OF  A  MOVIE  ALL  BY  IT'S  SELF,  THEN  THERE  CAME  RETURN  TO  CRANFORD,, THERE  WAS  NO  DOCTOR  AT  ALL,,  IT  SEEM  LIKE  THEY  DIDNOT  HAVE  A  CLUE  WHAT  WAS  GOING  ON,  NO  SENCE  AT  ALL,, PEOPLE  WOULD  JUST  LEAVE  AND  YOU  HAVE  NO  CLUE  WHAT  HAPPENED  TO  THEM ,AND  I  DO  LOVE  BBC  MOVIES  I  GAVE  RETURN  TO  CRANFORD  TWO  STARS,,  IT  REALLY  LEFT  ME  CONFUSED, AND  THESE  MOVIES  ARE  NOT  CHEAP

reviewText: When I first saw Elizabeth Gaskill's Cranford, I fell in love with it.  Return to Cranford is an extension of Cranford.  Although not as intricately woven as Cranford, Return to Cranford was still a delight to watch.  If you love period British movies, then this is a must for your collection.
summary: A must see if you like period British movies
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: Not quite as good as the original "Cranford" but still if you liked "Cranford" you will like "Return to Cranford". The characters you enjoyed are mostly there and it does tie up some loose strings. The whole series encouraged me to want to watch more Elizabeth Gaskell stories and I also recommend "Wives and Daughters", loved it!!!!
summary: How could you not like Judi Dench?
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: I am so glad to have found Season 2 of Cranford!But I do miss some of the surviving characters from Season 1.  Ah well... time marches on.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: Cranford is always a joy to watch - the cast of older, distinguished actors is wonderful and engaging, but I found this sequal a little shallower and less developed than the original series. I'm still working my way through the series, so this might be premature, but it's harder to be engaged with the younger, new members of the cast - especially Peggy.Also slightly disturbing is the change in the established characters appearance - it's very slight, but the whole cast seems to have gone blonde all of a sudden (but kept their brown eyebrows)... a small detail, but it's distracting from the content :-)Sorry! Otherwise a lovely, clean and engaging series
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: Gotta love 'em.  The series, gives such an interesting spin on spinsterhood.  I love that line, "I have spinster carved in my bones, and I've never been sick a day in my life."  Hilarious.But really, for a woman of that era who did not care to die in childbirth, or to be lying-in every 10th month, I can kind of see where spinsterhood might be a preferred option.  Especially if one had as amiable a gaggle of geese as these to hang out with.  Miss Pole (that was ... and still is) is priceless.I am enjoying this even more than Downton Abbey and Upstairs Downstairs, although both are fantastic.  I guess because there is some humor in it.  Kind of more like Vanity Fair in that way(the BBC version (wonderful!),not the Reese Witherspoon version(horrible!)).
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: This is a great movie and I was so happy to find it at such a good price!  Thank you again!
summary: Thank you for the great item and for your excellant service!
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: I enjoyed seeing what had happened in Cranford since the original DVD. Miss Mattie again came across as a caring person with a great dal of strength. The other ladies in the village still entertained. With a cast headed by Dame Judy Dench, how can you lose?  I will watch these DVDs again & again & I know I will enjoy them.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: This show is so great, I so wish they had more seasons. Anyway, the characters are well written and you are really taken by everyone of them. I find myself having emotions for all of them. I love shows that do this, I means isn't that why we watch to be taken away to another place even just for a little while.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: I only saw the first presentation on PBS and I am disappointed.  I loved "Cranford" and I wish that many more of the original cast were kept in the "Return."  Why was it necessary to lose Dr. Harrison and his new bride and leave Cranford with no doctor at all (hence the death of Martha).  A different actor for Matty's brother - Mary Smith's lack of eye glasses - and so many references to things past we must read all the books for answers.  What was Mary Smith's disappointment?  Hopefully, Septimus will not win out in the end.But, I have pre-ordered the DVD and I am sure I will perhaps learn to like it.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: I and my family really liked the first part of Crawford in spite of it's being so sad.We were pleased that it had very few bad words and few low dresses (just one or two where the neck line was a tad to low and one scene where the maid lay down inapropriatly) The second one was more interesting for us, fewer deaths of the people you liked, and even fewer bad words and kess inapropriat behavier.This part is a  SPOILER  for a small side part: we were disappointed however that they made Mary a bit of a feminism by braking off her engagement as an impediment  for her becoming a great authoress. But since she is not in the movie much and by the time you find out her choice you already care more for Peggy it is not to big of a deal.Modesty wise there is one part that is a little uncomfortable because of the way a man looks at a girl when he is asking if he might wipe the crumbs off of her skirt and the way he does it is very slow but that is all. tjere was on sort glimps of an inmodest picture in the third episod and in one episode Mary's stepmother is wearing an inmodest dress.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: Excellent performing and compact story lines. It is not trying to stretch out the story but pacted in.Beautilly setted lighting and great landscape views.Really love it. Hope soon Prime members can view Season 2 for free!! Cannot wait!!!
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: I also like the fact that it has some of my favorite actors like Tom Hiddlestone and Michelle Dockery {before she was Lady Mary on Downton Abbey}..and of course the great Judy Dench
summary: I loved the orginal Cranford and this one just as much to
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: I loved Cranford, and I loved Return to Cranford.  this period piece is set in the 1700 hundreds in a remote village called Cranford.  All the characters have very good parts and roles in their social circle.  You can't wait to the next episode, which is of course why I binge-watched the series...and then bought it.  I love Judi Dench, but there are no weak characters in this series.  And, it's family friendly.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: Loved the first series and this one did not disappoint either.I love the time period for many reasons: the acting, story, costumes scenery, buildings...and it is just easy enjoyment all around.
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: I was able to watch this follow-up toCranfordthanks to a particular website and I promptly pre-ordered the DVD as I loved "Cranford" and its host of interesting and eccentric characters (and yes, I am a period drama fan, especially of BBC productions). This is actually a 2-part special that is not only inspired by the original Cranford, but also two other stories by author Elizabeth Gaskell, i.e. "The Moorland Cottage", and also "The Cage at Cranford", seeThree Tales of Cranford: Cranford, The Cage at Cranford, and The Moorland Cottage. Besides the familiar and beloved cast of the original Cranford such as Miss Matty (Dame Judi Dench), Miss Pole (Imelda Staunton),  Mrs Forrester (Julia McKenzie), Miss Tomkinson (Deborah Findlay), etc. several new characters are introduced, such as Lady Glenmire (played by Celia Imrie), and the conjuror Signor Brunoni(Tim Curry).The first part is set in summer 1844 - it has been two years since dear Miss Matty (Dame Judi Dench in another luminous portrayal) lost her beloved sister Deborah, and a year since Sophy Hutton married Dr Harrison (these two characters are no longer in this show). Miss Matty seems content with the presence of her brother Peter (Nicholas Le Prevost) who is home from India, and helps look after Tilly, the baby of her maid Martha and carpenter Jem Hearne. The continuity from the original Cranford is seen in the railway project which still looms menacingly over the town. Things are also made more exciting with the arrival of Mr. Buxton, a wealthy widower who lives with his ward Erminia (Michelle Dockery) and his son William (Tom Hiddleston who is quite the eye candy). Life in Cranford is always full of surprises and when Lady Ludlow's long absent son Septimus (Rory Kinnear) arrives, things take unexpected turns, precipitated by a tragedy in the family. The old tensions are there - especially between those that are against the railroad project and those ,like Captain Brown and young William who feel that modernization is essential to Cranford's long-term survival. Miss Matty, in her usual subtle fashion, gets involved in some of these village proceedings, with some rather startling results.The second part is set later in the year 1844, October  up till Christmas - Miss Matty and her friends are predictably excited at the visit of Lady Glenmire (Celia Imrie) but when Mrs Jamieson (Barbara Flynn) feels no one amongst her peers is of suitably high rank to meet her, she and Lady Glenmire get snubbed by Matty and company and it is left to Lady Glenmire to set things right in a most memorable way. Matty also faces some challenges that involves a falling out amongst her circle of friends,a serious romance between William and a young woman deemed unsuitable by his father (which has Matty pondering the wisdom of her 'involvement' in bringing the pair together), and more tragedy on the horizon, affecting the citizens of Cranford.The magic of the original is still evident and this follow-up (of sorts - it's not strictly a sequel though some story arcs from the first Cranford get developed here) is still charming and engrossing. A fair note of warning, this particular installment in the Cranford franchise is much more subdued than the original and there's quite a fair bit of tragedy - there's death (involving a couple of familiar characters who were also in the original), grief, tension, family drama, imperiled friendships, the age-old battle between those opposed to change and those who embrace the challenges of modernization,etc., but there's also romance, lighthearted moments and even a bit of magic!The comic and the tragic are seamlessly blended into the story, resulting in an immensely satisfying viewing experience. I loved it though I can understand how this particular follow-up might disappoint purists who loved the original and how well it adhered to Gaskell's novel. As for the production qualities - they are excellent. The cinematography is gorgeous, capturing the beauty of the village surroundings as well as the period details, and the score complements the story perfectly. I wish I could be so lucky as to live in a place like Cranford!
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford

reviewText: I am a big fan of British series and this one fills the bill perfectly. Drama, comedy and love all rolled into one
Title: Cranford: Return to Cranford
